standard_metadata.standard_description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

question.content: Triangle $\triangle A'B'C'$ is the result of translating $\triangle ABC$ by $6$ units to the right and $2$ units down.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Triangle A B C has point A at negative two, three. Point B is at three, one. Point C is at one, negative three.

options.content: $\angle A$ and $\angle A'$ have the same measures.
$B$ and $B'$ have the same coordinates.
The areas of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$ are the same.

hints.content: Translations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Translations change the coordinates of every point in the figure.
Because the height and base of the triangle stay the same, so does the area.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$:**  - **$\angle A$ and $\angle A'$ have the same measure.** - **The areas of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$ are the same.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. Triangle A B C has point A at negative two, three. Point B is at three, one. Point C is at one, negative three. A translated triangle A prime B prime C prime is moved to the right and down.

question.content: Quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ is the result of translating quadrilateral $ABCD$ by $5$ units to the left and $5$ units down.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at negative six, negative five. Point B is at negative six, negative four. Point C is at negative three, negative two. Point D is at negative five, negative five.

options.content: $\angle C$ and $\angle C'$ have the same measures.
The areas of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ are the same.
The perimeters of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ are the same.

hints.content: Translations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Translations change the coordinates of every point in the figure.
Because the segment lengths stay the same, so does the perimeter.  Because the segment lengths and all of the angle measurements stay the same, so does the area.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$:**  - **$\angle C$ and $\angle C'$ have the same measures.** - **The areas of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ are the same.** - **The perimeters of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ are the same.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at negative six, negative five. Point B is at negative six, negative four. Point C is at negative three, negative two. Point D is at negative five, negative five. The quadrilateral is translated to the left and down to quadrilateral A prime B prime C prime D prime.

question.content: Segment $\overline{A'B'}$ is the result of translating $\overline{AB}$ by $1$ unit to the right and $3$ units up.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Line segment A B has endpoint A at two, negative six. Endpoint B is at two, negative three.

options.content: $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ are both parallel to the $y$-axis.
$\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ have the same lengths.
$B$ and $B'$ have the same coordinates.

hints.content: Translations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Translations change the coordinates of every point in the figure.
Translations take segments to segments that are parallel with the source. Since $\overline{AB}$ was already parallel with the $y$-axis, segment $\overline{A'B'}$ will be parallel, too.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$:**  - **$\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ are both parallel to the $y$-axis.** - **$\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ have the same lengths.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. Line segment A B has endpoint A at two, negative six. Endpoint B is at two, negative three. It is translated right and up to line segment A prime B prime.

question.content: Circle $A'$ is the result of translating circle $A$ by $2$ units to the right and $5$ units down.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of circle $A$ and circle $A'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A circle with a center A at one, negative two and a radius of three.

options.content: Points $A$ and $A'$ have the same coordinates.
Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same area.
The radii of circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same lengths.

hints.content: Translations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Translations change the coordinates of every point in the figure.
Since a radius is a kind of segment, its length remains the same under the transformation.  Because the radius remains the same, so does the area.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of circle $A$ and circle $A'$:**  - **Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same area.** - **The radii of circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same lengths.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A circle with a center A at one, negative two and a radius of three. It is translated right and down with a center A prime.

question.content: Quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ is the result of reflecting quadrilateral $ABCD$ across the line $\ell$.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A quadrilateral A B C D is in the first quadrant. A line of reflection starts at zero, zero and passes through Point C of the quadrilateral.

options.content: The perimeters of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ are the same.
$\overline{AD}$ and $\overline{A'D'}$ have the same lengths.
$C$ and $C'$ have the same coordinates.

hints.content: Reflections preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Reflections change the coordinates of every point in the figure except for those on the line of reflection.
Because each of the side lengths remains the same, so does the perimeter.  We note that $C$ is on the line of reflection, so the reflection leaves its coordinates unchanged.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$:**  - **The perimeters of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ are the same.** - **$\overline{AD}$ and $\overline{A'D'}$ have the same lengths.** - **$C$ and $C'$ have the same coordinates.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A quadrilateral A B C D is in the first quadrant. A line of reflection starts at zero, zero and passes through Point C of the quadrilateral. The quadrilateral is reflected across the line of reflection, making quadrilateral A prime B prime C prime D prime with point c prime mapped onto point c.

question.content: Triangle $\triangle A'B'C'$ is the result of reflecting $\triangle ABC$ across the line $\ell$.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A triangle A B C is in the third quadrant. A line of reflection slants downwards from negative four, zero through zero negative six. Triangle A B C had point A at zero, negative two, point B at negative five, negative seven, and point C at negative three, negative seven.

options.content: $\overline{BC}$ and $\overline{B'C'}$ are both perpendicular to the $y$-axis.
$\angle B$ and $\angle B'$ have the same measures.
The perimeters of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$ are the same.

hints.content: Reflections preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths within the figure.   Reflections change the coordinates of every point in the figure except for those on the line of reflection.
Because each of the side lengths remains the same, so does the perimeter.  After the reflection, $B'C'$ is not horizontal any longer, so it is not perpendicular to the $y$-axis.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$:**  - **$\angle B$ and $\angle B'$ have the same measures.** - **The perimeters of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$ are the same.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A triangle A B C is in the third quadrant. A line of reflection slants downwards from negative four, zero through zero negative six. Triangle A B C had point A at zero, negative two, point B at negative five, negative seven, and point C at negative three, negative seven. It is reflected, making triangle A prime B prime C prime with points B prime and C prime in the fourth quadrant with different y-values.

question.content: Segment $\overline{A'B'}$ is the result of reflecting $\overline{AB}$ across line $\ell$.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A line segment A B has endpoint A at negative two, three and endpoint B at negative five, six. A line of reflection slants down from left to right passing through negative two, three and zero, two.

options.content: $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ have the same lengths.
$B$ and $B'$ have the same coordinates.

hints.content: Reflections preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Reflections change the coordinates of every point in the figure except for those on the line of reflection.

**This is the correct statement about the unchanged properties of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$:**  - **$\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ have the same lengths.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A line segment A B has endpoint A at negative two, three and endpoint B at negative five, six. A line of reflection l slants down from left to right passing through negative two, three and zero, two. The line segment A B is reflected across the line of reflection making line segment A prime B prime with point A prime being mapped onto point A.

question.content: Circle $A'$ is the result of reflecting circle $A$ across the line $\ell$.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of circle $A$ and circle $A'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A circle with a center at negative six, negative six and a radius of two. A line of reflection l slants down from left to right passing through negative one, negative two and zero, negative five.

options.content: The radii of circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same lengths.
Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same circumference.
Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same area.

hints.content: Reflections preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Reflections change the coordinates of every point in the figure except for those on the line of reflection.
Since a radius is a kind of segment, its length remains the same under the transformation.  Because the radius remains the same, so do the circumference and the area.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of circle $A$ and circle $A'$:**  - **The radii of circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same lengths.** - **Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same circumference.** - **Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same area.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A circle with a center A at negative six, negative six and a radius of two. A line of reflection l slants down from left to right passing through negative one, negative two and zero, negative five. The circle is reflected across the line of reflection into the fourth quadrant with center A prime.

question.content: Quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$ is the result of rotating quadrilateral $ABCD$ by $60^\circ$ about the origin.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at three, negative two. Point B is at five, four. Point C is at five, one. Point D is at four, negative one. There is a point at zero, zero.

options.content: $\overline{BC}$ and $\overline{B'C'}$ are both parallel to the $y$-axis.
$\angle B$ and $\angle B'$ have the same measures.
$D$ and $D'$ have the same coordinates.

hints.content: Rotations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths within the figure.   Rotations change the coordinates of every point in the figure except on the center of rotation.
Rotation changes the angle between the $y$-axis and segment $\overline{BC}$, so the segment is not parallel with the axis anymore.

**This is the correct statement about the unchanged properties of quadrilateral $ABCD$ and quadrilateral $A'B'C'D'$:**  - **$\angle B$ and $\angle B'$ have the same measures.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]  [[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. Quadrilateral A B C D has point A at three, negative two. Point B is at five, four. Point C is at five, one. Point D is at four, negative one. There is a point at zero, zero. The quadrilateral A B C D is rotated sixty degrees counterclockwise about the origin making quadrilateral A prime B prime C prime D prime.

question.content: Triangle $\triangle A'B'C'$ is the result of rotating $\triangle ABC$ by $-135^\circ$ about point $A$.        **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A triangle A B C. Triangle A B C has point A at negative three, one, point B at negative five, negative six, and point C at negative two, negative two.

options.content: $A$ and $A'$ have the same coordinates.
The perimeters of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$ are the same.
$\angle C$ and $\angle C'$ have the same measures.

hints.content: Rotations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Rotations change the coordinates of every point in the figure except on the center of rotation.
We note that $A$ is on the center of rotation, so the rotation leaves its coordinates unchanged.  Because the segment lengths stay the same, so does the perimeter.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$:**  - **$A$ and $A'$ have the same coordinates.** - **The perimeters of $\triangle ABC$ and $\triangle A'B'C'$ are the same.** - **$\angle C$ and $\angle C'$ have the same measures.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A triangle A B C. Triangle A B C has point A at negative three, one, point B at negative five, negative six, and point C at negative two, negative two. The triangle is rotated negative one hundred thirty five degrees about point A to make triangle A prime B prime C prime with point A prime mapped onto point A.

question.content: Segment $\overline{A'B'}$ is the result of rotating $\overline{AB}$ by $90^\circ$ about point $P$.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A line segment with endpoints A at one, negative two and B at negative two, negative two.  Point P is plotted at negative four, negative one.

options.content: $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ are both perpendicular to the $x$-axis.
$A$ and $A'$ have the same coordinates.
$\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ have the same lengths.

hints.content: Rotations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Rotations change the coordinates of every point in the figure except on the center of rotation.
While the rotation does make $\overline{A'B'}$ perpendicular to the $x$-axis, the source image $\overline{AB}$ is parallel to the $x$-axis instead.

**This is the correct statement about the unchanged properties of $\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$:**  - **$\overline{AB}$ and $\overline{A'B'}$ have the same lengths.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A line segment with endpoints A at one, negative two and B at negative two, negative two.  Point P is plotted at negative four, negative one. The line segment is rotated ninety degrees about point P, making the line segment A prime B prime.

question.content: Circle $A'$ is the result of rotating circle $A$ by $180^\circ$ about point $P$.      **Select all of the correct statements about the unchanged properties of circle $A$ and circle $A'$.**

images.alt: A coordinate plane. The x- and y-axes both scale by one. A circle with a center at negative three, zero and a radius of two. A point P is plotted at one, negative two.

options.content: Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same circumference.
The radii of circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same lengths.
Points $A$ and $A'$ are both on the $x$-axis.

hints.content: Rotations preserve (keep the same) angle measures and segment lengths.   Rotations change the coordinates of every point in the figure except on the center of rotation.

Since a radius is a kind of segment, its length remains the same under the transformation.  Because the radius remains the same, so does the circumference.  After the rotation, point $A'$ would be in quadrant $\text{IV}$, not on the $x$-axis.

**These are the correct statements about the unchanged properties of circle $A$ and circle $A'$.**  - **The radii of circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same lengths.** - **Circle $A$ and circle $A'$ have the same circumference.**  If we graph the transformation, we can see for ourselves which properties remained unchanged.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A blank coordinate plane. A circle with a center A at negative three, zero and a radius of two. A point P is plotted at one, negative two. The circle is rotated one hundred eighty degrees about point P, making a circle with a center A prime.
